awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrating two different roles of the proton-pumping pyrophosphatase in the regulation and efficiency of carbon utilization and transport in planta
awd_abstract_narration:
Plant productivity is determined in large part by the partitioning of reduced carbon (sugar) between the sites of production (photosynthetic tissues) and the sites of utilization (growing tissues such as roots and young leaves, etc). To judiciously engineer increased yield of crop plants, a better understanding of the regulation and efficiency of sugar transport throughout the plant is required. Work by the principal investigators and others has shown that the up-regulation of proton-pyrophosphatases (H+-PPases) results in enhanced root and shoot growth and increased photosynthetic output. The principal investigators hypothesize that plant H+-PPases play a crucial role in regulating sucrose synthesis, partitioning and utilization.  The  hypotheses will be tested using a combination of genetic, metabolomic, molecular biological, and ultra-structural approaches. The research will shed light not only on the fundamental physiological subject of carbon utilization and transport, but also has  potential downstream applications since increased H+-PPase activity enhances plant biomass, nutrient uptake capacities, and stress tolerance. With growing populations, decreasing arable land, and a national desire to exploit plants for biofuels, understanding the role of H+-PPases in plant growth could be transformative. 

The outcomes of this project will be made available to the scientific community through timely publication and by the participation of the principal investigators in their undergraduate and graduate education programs.  The professional development of undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows will occur at the interface of genetics, physiology, cell biology and cutting-edge metabolomics. The project participants will work together with the Arizona State University "Ask a Biologist" program to develop topical content on biomass for fuel and how it relates to the movement of energy throughout biological systems.

por.por_cntn:
All plants perform photosynthesis. In this process, plants use protons (H+) from water and the energy from sunlight to reduce atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) to make energy-dense sugar molecules. Plants have chloroplasts in their leaves, and these chloroplasts are the sites of this light-dependent sugar synthesis. The sugar needs to be transported from the source (i.e. leaves) to other parts of the plant where photosynthesis is insufficient (like in young leaves) or non-existent (like in roots). These sugar-consuming parts of the plant are called sinks. Analogous to arteries and veins in animals, plants have a circulatory network of cells called the phloem that connects the source and sink tissues through which the sugars are transported. This means that the process by which sugar gets loaded into the phloem at the sites of sugar synthesis and transported to sink tissues is vital in plant growth and function. The potential of regulating the translocation of sugar from source to sink tissues represents an opportunity to increase the yield of many important crops. The better a plant delivers sugar, the faster it is utilized in biomass production, and this flux increases the need of higher photosynthetic rates that, in turn, consume more CO2 from the atmosphere.

 

As mentioned earlier, the proper functioning of the phloem is critical for the loading and transport of sugar in the plant. There are many factors involved in normal phloem function. Earlier scientific work suggests that a balanced turnover of a molecule called pyrophosphate (PPi) is one of the most factors in maintaining proper phloem function. Though PPi is known to be important in the phloem, the source of its supply in the phloem has remained mysterious.

 

Previous work from the Gaxiola laboratory suggested that a protein called the Proton-pumping pyrophosphatase (H+-PPase) was involved in normal phloem function. Contrary to the generally accepted idea that this protein consumes PPi, the Gaxiola group hypothesized that this protein (H+-PPase) would produce PPi in the phloem. This grant allowed the Gaxiola laboratory to gather genetic (presence or expression levels of genes), physiological (physical parameters of growth), and immunohistochemical (visualization of proteins in tissues) evidence in support of the group’s hypothesis.  The knowledge generated from this research has promising agbiotechnological applications related to improving crop productivity.

 

This research yielded six peer-reviewed publications in prestigious journals. The funds were also used to educate and train students and researchers at different career levels – ranging from undergraduates to post-doctoral fellows. Under this research project, two undergraduate students successfully wrote and defended their honors theses, and one PhD student is currently nearing completion. Two post-doctoral fellows that participated in the research also trained undergraduate and graduate students in key laboratory skills, and also taught some undergraduate level classes. The PI trained both postdoctoral fellows in manuscript and grant proposal writing. The results were also disseminated to scientific peers in twelve national and international meetings. To have a broader societal impact, we also developed a web-based K-12 resource on topical content titled "Phosphate Fix: The sweet side of greens" in collaboration with the Arizona State University’s Ask a Biologist (https://askabiologist.asu.edu/explore/phosphate-fix) program.

Modified by: Roberto Gaxiola
